Mary M. Johnson

Mary Johnson began her career with the Department of Correction as a VISTA volunteer in 1984 working both at the Hartford Correctional Center and with project FIRE, a DOC Addiction Services initiative. In 1985 she was hired as a Correctional Services Aide Trainee at the Brooklyn Correctional Institution. She was the first female staff member working in the security side of that facility. While there she ascended through the treatment ranks. She worked in Addiction Services, classification and case management. In 1990 she was promoted to Counselor Supervisor at that facility.

In November of 1992 she was appointed as Warden of the Hartell DWI unit in Windsor Locks and shortly after was transferred to the Brooklyn Correctional Institution as that facility's Warden.

In April 1995 Mary Johnson was appointed to Warden of the Walker Reception and Special Management Unit in Suffield where she was given the task of implementing a Chronic Discipline Unit and a High Bond unit for pretrial inmates. She was also responsible for overseeing the Department's statewide transportation unit.

In October of 1996 she was appointed as Warden of the Corrigan Correctional Institution and in August of 1997 she was reassigned to the Hartford Correctional Center, the state's most active pre-trial facility. In February 2000, she was transferred to the recently consolidated Willard-Cybulski Correctional Institution, a highly programmatic facility with numerous community-based initiatives. On May 1, 2001, she was appointed to the Manson Youth Institution in Cheshire. In March 2003 Commissioner Theresa C. Lantz appointed Johnson Director of Programs and Treatment for the agency.

Mary Johnson is a 1983 Honors Scholar, graduating Summa Cum Laude, from the University of Connecticut and holds a Bachelor of Science Degree in Human Development and Family Relations.

In 1992 Ms. Johnson was selected as the Department's Employee of the Year and also honored with the Department's Distinguished Service Award.

Director Johnson has served on numerous boards, including: Literacy Volunteers of America, Advisory Board for Three Rivers Community-Technical College, and is presently the senior Connecticut member on the board of the Middle Atlantic States Correctional Association (MASCA) where she has served since 1991.

Mary Johnson is a Sister of Notre Dame de Namur and an associate professor of sociology and religious studies at Emmanuel College in Boston. She received her B.A. from Emmanuel and her M.A. and Ph.D. from the University of Massachusetts at Amherst. She is co-author of Young Adult Catholics, a national study of religious beliefs and practices of Catholics between the ages of 20 and 39. Sr. Johnson is currently working on a national study of religious orders of women with special emphasis on post-Vatican II entrants, funded by the Lilly Endowment. Her work has appeared in Catholic periodicals and in sociology journals, and she has spoken to national conferences of the Catholic Campus Ministry Association, the National Young Adult Ministry Association, and the Leadership Conference of Women Religious. She has received a Future Leader in American Religion Fellowship at the Duke University Divinity School and was awarded the national Harvest Award by the National Religious Vocation Conference. Sr. Johnson serves on the Board of Trustees of Trinity College in Washington, D.C., the Board of Directors of the Center for Applied Research in the Apostolate at Georgetown University, and the Catholic Common Ground Initiative.

johnson

21 and 17-19 Seventh St.--the Johnson home on the left and the old Friends Meetinghouse on the right
National Historic Landmarks photograph

 


21 and 17-19 Seventh St.--Johnson home on the left, Friends Meetinghouse to the right
National Historic Landmarks photograph
ma6
Nathan and Mary Johnson were free blacks living in New Bedford, Massachusetts, who owned a block of properties including their longtime home and the neighboring old Friends meetinghouse. Nathan Johnson was an active abolitionist who assisted numerous fugitive slaves, including famous abolitionist Frederick Douglass. The Johnson home was Douglass's first residence after his escape from slavery in 1838--the only one of Douglass's three homes in New Bedford that remains today. These properties have been recognized as National Historic Landmarks.

At the end of 1853, the population of New Bedford was comprised of a higher percentage of African Americans than any other city in the Northeast, and almost 30% of those residents claimed they were born in the South. New Bedford was attractive to fugitive slaves and free blacks in part because of its major industries, the whaling and maritime trades, which have historically been the most welcoming occupations to people of all races. New Bedford also demonstrated a certain tolerance of diversity, and black leaders of the time were impressed with the political activity and degree of social organization among the city's people of color, coupled with some access to capital and integration in schools and some neighborhoods and workplaces. This black community was composed of vehement abolitionists and abolitionist supporters who were the audience of every principal antislavery lecturer in the United States. The city was appealing to fugitive slaves, and their population in New Bedford ranged at any time from 300 to 700.

Nathan and Mary Johnson married in New Bedford in 1819 and by the 1840s had well established economic means. They owned a confectioner's shop and other businesses, were well read in the political and social conditions of the nation and willing to help the abolitionist cause in many ways. Nathan Johnson was a steadfast delegate to the annual convention of free people of color from 1832-1835 and was elected the president of the 1847 National Convention of Colored People in Troy, New York. He and his wife also supported the movement by harboring fugitive slaves in their home. William C. Taber and Joseph Ricketson, two New Bedford Quakers, brought Frederick Douglass and his family to the Johnson home in September 1838. They resided there until 1839. The fact that Taber and Ricketson brought the Douglass family to the Johnsons suggests that the Johnson household was a common safe house for slaves in search of their freedom. Douglass himself attests to Nathan Johnson's regular practice of assisting fugitive slaves in all three of his well-known narratives. It is believed that the old Friends meetinghouse was a safe house for runaway slaves as well, however this has not been confirmed. The meetinghoue was not only the first house of public worship in New Bedford, but also the site of Benjamin Lundy's 1828 antislavery address.

The Nathan and Mary Johnson Properties are located at 17-19 and 21 Seventh St., in New Bedford, Massachusetts. Both buildings are privately owned, and are not open to the public.

Main Street: Bill & Mary Johnson

Fifty-eight years ago, an ambitious and eager 9 year old delivery boy delivers meat on his bicycle to the wealthy estates of Greenwich, Connecticut for three dollars a day. He sings for the boys' choir on Sundays, and is often disciplined for his talkative nature. The boy lives during a time in which air-raid sirens are a common occurrence. His father tells him: "A busy kid is a kid who stays out of trouble." The boy stays busy, plays three sports, works hard in school, and perseveres. The boy becomes the mayor of Saco, Maine.

Bill and Mary Johnson are more than inhabitants of Saco: they are innovators. Since they moved here permanently, 13 years ago, Bill and Mary have been as active in the community and state as possible. Just take a look at their list of community service: Bill as City counselor, mayor of Saco, Development board for TA, UMaine Audit committee, and trustee for Portland Symphony Orchestra, and Mary as a member of the T.A.Alumni Association, the Wardwell Board of Directors, Salvation Army Community Advisory Board and Dyer-York Community Relations. That does not include their work at their church, and his work in Massachusetts as a public official. Bill is completing his 24th year as an elected public official -- 12 in Massachusetts and 12 in Saco, Maine.

"People too many times sit back and pick things apart, and complain about things, but I try to have a different approach. I want to do something to make it right," says Mayor Johnson in his trademark, booming voice.

To the Johnsons, it only makes sense to give back to the community "because it has been good to us." Mobil Oil Corporation, Bill's employer for 35 years, encouraged him to get involved. "Mobil was very good at telling us to get involved and make a difference in our community," says Mayor Johnson. Bill seems to credit Mobil for the success he has experienced throughout his career.

He graduated from the University of Maine at Orono with degrees in business and economics and was immediately employed by Mobil Oil out of college. Starting out at a service station, he spent a year "greasing cars, cleaning restrooms, learning from the ground up." Slowly, he worked his way through the ranks of management, until he became Boston District Manager and managed retail sales in New England. He closed out his career as Wholesale Manager of the northeast. Despite his success in the oil business, it did cause some hardships on family life. Because of his occupation, Bill was forced to transfer often, because "in the beginning you couldn't really say no to promotions or you wouldn't be given other opportunities," says Mary. "One time they wanted him to go to Kansas City, and I said, 'Bill, I'm from Maine, I have to be near an ocean! I will wither up and dry up and blow away!'"

Although there were eight moves, the Johnsons were able to stay in New England and raise three children, all of whom, not surprisingly, have succeeded in business. "We have three children, and their work ethics are outstanding! That's the thing my parents passed on, and fortunately both of us have been able to pass it on to them," says Bill.

In the passing of generation to generation, both Mary and Bill hold strong to values of hard work, honesty, family bonds, and faith led guidance. Even now, with all their children grown up, they are still strongly involved in their church. Both Bill and Mary are active members in the first Parish Congregational Church of Saco.Elected as Moderator after the historic church burned in a devastating fire in 2000, Mary is leading the church in its efforts to rebuild on the corner of Beach and Main Street. Bill holds his own in the church also. Almost every Sunday, you can hear his booming bass voice coming from the group of choir singers.

"The church has meant a lot to us," says Mary. "And we were both brought up that way, with our faith heritage. And it's important that we try just by the way we live, and the way we worship to hand that onteach it to our kids."

Mary has been closely tied to the church since high school, when she worked as counselor at a church camp for inner city children from Boston, and then in college where she worked a summer in Vermont, teaching Vacation Bible schools in rural churches. "Living and working with thos

Ancestor Stories
Mary Johnson-Ligons-Moss and Katie Miller, Winchester, VA
Ahhh......Katie Miller & Mary Johnson-Ligons-Moss, their lives intertwined in life and death. They left us with sadness and anger. Why anger? There are too many unanswered questions they both took to their graves. GGmother Mary personified the word LOYALTY! She was as closed mouth as the Millers.

We were told by an elderly cousin that Mary was the go between for the Miller women who had children born out of wedlock. She was closer to Katie than anyone else. Yes, my thinking is that Thomas had an afffair with one of the women. GGrandfather Thomas wasn't your typical black male. He was a tall, wellspoken, handsome mulatto with a very imposing stature that when he walked into a room, he automatically received the attention of those present.

He worked for Richard Byrd, an attorney in Winchester, Va. as a man servant. This is the Byrd family of Rear Admiral Byrd and the politicians from Va. W. Va. Thomas received his education by being privy to the conversations held in the Byrd household. I must give the Byrd family credit as they list the genealogy of their "Black Family".

I started reseaching our family fours years ago and spent most of the time running into this brick wall surrounding the Miller Plantation in Winchester, Va. where Mary went to live at the age of five, given to Katie Miller as a Christmas present.

Innuendo and supposition, that's all I had to go by until I found out that we had an elderly cousin in Winchester. My mother is still alive but in a nursing home in Md. and not able to communicate so I had to resort to contacting Richmond, Va., the census, family stories, etc. The rest of that generation were deceased and were a product of that "closed mouth society!"

Mary received her release from slavery at the age of 21 according to the will of Rebecca Miller. She continued working for the family until well into her 70's.

Thomas and Mary had a son (?) named Charles Franklin Moss.
We doubt that Mary is his mother. Why, well in the family bible under the records of his birth is this notation....(Was g--en to Mary) What else could the missing word be but "GIVEN!" According to Frederick County Va. records, Mary and Thomas were married in 1877 but in the 1880 US Census, she is not listed as his wife. In those days marriage certiicates weren't issued and you could register providing the clerk with whatever information you wish providing both parties agreed.

When Aunt Mary (as the Miller Family referred to her) became ill, a member of the Miller family took her back to the Miller home where she died in 1926.

Last year I came upon a copy of her obituary that was written by the Miller family which I found a little strange as Mary still had quite a large family still in Winchester and Pa. But finally, right there in the obituary, staring me in the face was a daunting, powerful statement that made me realize that I would never be able to complete the Moss puzzle. One short line stated......."she was faithful to every trust reposed to her".

Charles Frankin Moss born in 1878, mother shown on birth register as Mary. Slaves kept their children on the plantation and they worked right along with the other help. Not Charles, he never lived there. He was raised by his Aunt Gertrude right along with her children. Charles was as well dressed and educated as any white child of means. He was gifted with artisic ability and at the age of fourteen painted a mural across the altar of the Moss family church, Mount Carmel Baptist in Winchester called "The Lamb of God!"

Several years later he studied in Providence and Newport Rhode Island.Then he enrolled for postgraduate art study as Cooper-Union School of Fine Arts in New York City. While there he studied sculpting with a private tutor. Later he was admitted to the Pa. Academy of fine Arts and together with noted artist Henry O. Tanner were the first of their race to be honored. He received many more accolades and "first of his race" but more important to my research was the fact that he and Henry told everyone that they were half-brothers. You see, Tanner's mother came from the same Miller plantation. Her grandfather was the plantation owner. Both families eventually settled in Carlisle, Pa.

The only people that had the wherewithal to cater to his artistic
ability by providing the schooling, travel, housing and supplies were the Miller's. Oh, in Mary's obit, they did make mention of Charles having a half-sister, but that's another story. You see, she has the last name of a Miller in-law!

The Miller family has two genealogy listings located in the Handley Library in Winchester. One is for public viewing and the other is "sealed!" There lies the unanswered questions that both the Mosses & Tanners are seeking. I hope they both are resting in peace.

Sheila Green-Stevenson
Daughter of Ruth Moss-Green (last surviving grandaughter)

Johnson Family

First Generation:

William Johnson was born August 31, 1732 in Wales, Great Britain and died in 1765 in Old Rowan County (present day Forsyth), North Carolina. He married Elizabeth Ellis and they had two children, James and Sarah. After William's death in 1765 his widow, Elizabeth, married Robert Willson. The parcel of land that William Johnson bought upon his arrival in 1757 from William Linville, is the present-day site of Tanglewood Park, Clemmons, NC.

Most records indicate that James Johnson was born at sea in 1757 on the way to America. It is unknown where he is buried but his will was probated August 30, 1830 in Rowan County, NC.

Mt. Pleasant Methodist Church, Clemmons vicinity

Mt. Pleasant Methodist Church was constructed in 1809 by Henry Eccles, a local builder, who carved his initials and the date into one of the church timbers. It is a simple, frame, gable-front structure which housed an active congregation until the 1920s. In 1928 William Neal Reynolds bought the property at the request of the congregation and the building was used as a granary. It was restored in 1951 through the generosity of Senah Critz Kent. Next to the church lies a graveyard with stones dating from 1765. William Johnson, the first settler in the area, is buried in the cemetery. --Courtesy of the City-County Planning Board, Winston Salem, North Carolina. All Rights Reserved.

  • Mt. Pleasant Cemetery Records by Virginia Flesher

    In October of 1853, Jeremiah Eccles offered his Plantation on the Yadkin River to be sold. The ad appeared in People's Press as follows: "I offer for sale my Plantation on Yadkin River, three miles South of Clemmonsville, containing 340 acres of land. The Improvements consist of a good two-story Dwelling, Kitchen, two Barns, other necessary Outhouses, and two Wells of good water conveniently situated. There is a good Mill-Seat of about five feet fall on the premises, with water sufficent to propel any quantity of Machinery. -- Jeremiah Eccles. Davidson County, N.C., Sept."

Mary Johnson and Benjamin Sewell




      Mary Johnson (1788- ?) was the first born to Thomas H. Johnson and Fanny Dickenson Scott Johnson. Mary married Benjamin Sewell of Russell County, Virginia, which is now Lee County, Virginia. This family moved to Claiborne County, Tennessee some time during their marriage, where eight children were born. We understand that this marriage ended in a divorce.

We have only partial information on one of their children, who are listed below:

(1) Thomas Sewell
(2) Susanna W. Sewell
(3) Elizabeth D. Sewell(1805-1884)Henry Dickenson Burdine (1 ch)
(4) Matilda Sewell
(5) Benjamin Sewell, Jr.
(6) William Sewell
(7) Malinda A. Sewell
(8) John Henry Harmon Sewell

      We are not sure of the correct name for the last child. Due to the divorce, it is possible that Mary could have married a person by the name of Harmon, thus the name John Henry Harmon. However, we are showing him as a Sewell.

Laura is not the first person in her family to join an apprenticeship program--her husband completed an apprenticeship for electricians! They both had the same field representative from the US Department of Labor!

Johanna Vaczy has been Laura's supervisor fro her apprenticeship.

Patricia Casey has been working with Marcy for the 2 year process. Marcy was one of the speakers for the Recognition Ceremony, sharing her thoughts as she completed the Program. Patricia will be continuing as a supervisor for a new apprentice at Mary Johnson while another supervisor is temporarily out of the child care center.

Amy's supervisor, Ann Rubright, has recently signed on with a new apprentice for another 2-year commitment.

Sue Hall's Director writes: "Sue's ever-growing confidence has been the at the core of everything the Apprenticeship Program has meant to her. She has successfully incorporated coursework into action and has developed a greater understanding of early childhood education as a whole"

Letters Re: Computer Access in the Lynwood Community
Lynwood School District Community Report Card

by Mary Johnson

You would think that every student would have access to computers. Not so in the Lynwood School District. Schools may have computers but our children aren’t using them. We found out while doing our investigations that there might be one to no computers in the classrooms. We did see more computers in GATE students’ rooms more than in regular classrooms. The computers that we do have are out of date or have no software installed. Maybe of our children are short-changed because Lynwood doesn’t have a grant writer to take advantage of grants for computer labs like other school districts.

Our district has an estimated 100 computers sitting in the Assistant Technology lab not being used on any given day. We learned that all Department Heads and some staff at the District level have lap top computers and, yet, students go without access. In Lynwood you have a lot of students with learning disabilities without assistant technology, but you have Department heads having top of the line technology. We think there is something wrong with this picture. We need to prepare our children so they can be competitive in society and successful in school and in the job markets. We were surveying school sites regarding computer access for students and parents. Some of the administrators weren’t very friendly and refused to give public information to parents and community members. Questions were asked like, why do you want this information? What are you going to do with this information? Or they asked us to bring a letter from our organization even though our children attend Lynwood School District.

Lynwood School District Report Card

Computer Access for Students F
Computer Access for Parents F
Preparing Students to be Competitive F
Empowerment of your Community F

Computer Neighbor vs. Non Computer Neighbors

If your community has computer access thank your lucky stars. Communities that have computers available are preparing their residents to be competitive in the job markets. Some school districts and cities partner with non-profit organizations to build computer accessible parent centers. As we move into the 21st Century assistant technology age, there are still some communities in the dark ages. Knowledge of computer literacy can improve earning potential. Some neighborhoods are voting on bills to deal with these issues.

Some of the advantages to having computer access are as follows:

1) White-collar jobs vs. physical labor jobs.
2) Students with computers are better prepared for class vs. Students with limited resources to prepare for class.
3) Parents with computer training who have a high-earning potential vs. Parents with no computer training who aren’t prepared for the 21st century and who will make minimum wage.

If your community doesn’t have computer access at your local churches, parks, teen centers, or schools, talk to your city and county officials and ask them to help the community by building a computer accessible neighborhood. Let your community officials know that there are grants, city funds, and county funds to assist them in bringing computers into their community.

It’s Just My Opinion

Computer access is limited in low-income neighborhoods. In my investigation I found out Lynwood was one of those communities not meeting the needs of its residents. The City of Lynwood isn’t computer access friendly with its residents. Sometimes I ask myself, does the city have the obligation to prepare its residents to be competitive in life? The answer I come up with is always yes. A community is only as good as the people living in it. When the Parent Project went out into the community to map out access to computers, there was only one place that had computers and that was the library. The library only has 10 computers and you have to make an appointment, as there is a waiting time of 1 – 2 hours. Many times half of the computers at the library are down and people have to wait up two days to use them. Lynwood has a beautiful Teen Center and Recreation Center for the youths, and only one computer for employees to use. I observed that Lynwood has a Skate Park, Basketball Courts, Tennis Courts, and other sports equipment, but stops short of making children competitive in society by purchasing computers for children to use at the center. It seems like some of our city officials are out of touch with the needs of our youth. We need to balance fun and education to equal the playing ground for our youths. We need to give our children all the opportunities to be competitive in school and in the job market. Every city official has a computer and a cell phone, but they have not made their neighborhood accessible to residents in their community. I found out that the city has a grant writer that writes grant for recreation, but doesn’t see writing grants for computer labs as important as sports.

In my opinion, computer labs can help our children and parents become better students and achieve job readiness.

Mary Johnson is a Parent Liaison for the Lynwood Parent Project.

 Calificaciones Comunitarias para el Distrito Escolar de Lynwood

por Mary Johnson

Se piensa que todos los estudiantes tienen acceso a computadoras. Pues ese no es el caso en el Distrito Escolar de Lynwood. Las escuelas pueden tener computadoras pero nuestros hijos no las están usando. En nuestra investigación encontramos que los salones de clases pueden tener una computadora o no tener ninguna. Vimos que hay más computadoras en los salones de estudiantes GATE que en los salones regulares. Las computadoras existentes no son modernas ni están programadas. Tal vez nuestros hijos estén perdiendo oportunidades porque Lynwood no tiene una persona que escriba propuestas para obtener dinero para computadoras como lo hay en otras escuelas del distrito.

Nuestro distrito tiene aproximadamente 100 computadoras en la sala de Asistencia Tecnológica que no son usadas en un determinado día. Encontramos que muchos de los Jefes de Departamento del distrito y algunos del personal tienen computadoras portátiles mientras que muchos estudiantes no tienen acceso. En Lynwood hay muchos estudiantes que tienen problemas de aprendizaje que no tienen asistencia tecnológica pero los Jefes de Departamiento tienen lo más nuevo de la tecnología. Nosotros creemos que hay algo mal en este caso. Necesitamos preparar a nuestros hijos para que sean competentes en la sociedad, en la escuela, y en el trabajo. Investigamos a distintas escuelas acerca del acceso a computadoras para padres y estudiantes. Algunos de los administradores no fueron muy amables y se negaron a dar información pública a los padres de familia y miembros de la comunidad. Preguntaron porqué quieren esta información? Qué van a hacer con esta información? También nos pidieron que trajeramos una carta de la organización que nos había mandado a pesar de que nuestros asisten al Distrito Escolar de Lynwood.

Calificaciones para el Distrito Escolar de Lynwood

Acceso a computadoras para estudiantes F
Acceso a computadoras para padres F
Preparación estudiantil para ser competentes F
Educación y Poder a la Comunidad F

Comunidades con computadoras vs. Comunidades sin computadoras

Si su comunidad tiene acceso a computadoras dele gracias a sus estrellas de la suerte. Las comunidades que tienen acceso a computadoras están preparando a sus residentes a ser más competentes en el mundo del trabajo. Algunos distritos escolares y ciudades se unen con organizaciones no lucrativas para crear centros para padres con acceso a computadoras. Conforme nos movemos hacia la era tecnológica del siglo XXI, siguen habiendo muchas comunidades en el pasado. El saber como usar computadoras puede mejorar el potencial salarial. Algunas comunidades están votando por leyes que tratan estos temas.

Algunas de las ventajas de tener acceso a las computadoras:

1) Trabajos intelectuales vs. trabajos manuales
2) Los estudiantes con computadoras están más preparados para sus clases vs. estudiantes con limitaciones para prepararse para sus clases.
3) Padres con conocimiento sobre computadoras que tienen alto potencial de salario vs. padres sin conocimiento sobre computadoras que no están preparados para el siglo XXI y que ganarán sueldo mínimo.

Si su comunidad no tiene acceso a computadoras en las iglesias locales, parques, centros juveniles, o escuelas, hable con sus representantes del condado o de la ciudad para que ayuden a su comunidad creando comunidades con acceso a computadoras. Dejeles saber a sus representantes comunitarios que existen becas, fondos de la ciudad, y fondos del condado para asistirlos a que traigan computadoras a su comunidad.

Es sólo mi opinión

El acceso a computadoras es limitado en las comunidades de salarios bajos. En mi investigación, encontré que Lynwood es una de esas comunidades que no satisface las necesidades de sus residentes. La ciudad de Lynwood no tiene acceso a computadoras para sus residentes. Algunas veces me pregunto, tiene la ciudad la responsabilidad de preparar a sus residentes para ser competentes en la vida? La respuesta siempre es sí. Una comunidad solo es tan buena como los residentes que viven en ella. Cuando el Proyecto de Padres salió a la comunidad para hacer un mapa del acceso a computadoras, solo había un lugar en el cual había computadoras: la biblioteca. La biblioteca solo tiene 10 computadoras y uno tiene que hacer cita siendo que hay un tiempo de espera aproximadamente de 1 a 2 horas. Muchas veces, la mitad de las computadoras en la biblioteca no sirven y las personas tienen que esperar hasta dos días para usarlas. Lynwood tiene un Centro Juvenil y Centro de Recreación para Jóvenes muy hermoso, y sólo una computadora para uso del personal. Observé que Lynwood tiene un parque estatal, canchas de basketbol, canchas de tennis, y otras cosas deportivas, pero se queda corto en hacer a nuestros hijos competentes en la sociedad comprando computadoras para que nuestros hijos las usen en el centro. Parece que muchos de los representantes guvernamentales de la comunidad no saben lo que nuestra juventud necesita. Necesitamos balancear la diversión y la educación para igualar el nivel entre nuestra juventud. Necesitamos darle a nuestra juventud las oportunidades para ser competentes en la escuela y en el mundo profesional. Todo oficial de la ciudad tiene una computadora y un celular pero no han hecho las comunidades accesibles para los residentes de su comunidad. Me enteré que la ciudad tiene una persona que escribe propuestas financieras para recreación, pero no vé la importancia de escribir propuestas para obtener computadoras como lo hace para los deportes.

En mi opinión, las salas de computadoras pueden ayudar a los estudiantes y padres a convertirse en mejores estudiantes y lograr estar listos para el mundo del empleo.

Mary Johnson es representante de padres del Proyecto de Padres en Lynwood.

Home > Campus Life > Volunteering > Opportunities Guide > Mary Johnson Children's Center

Mary Johnson Children's Center

81 Water Street

Middlebury, VT 05753

Contact: Barbara Saunders

802-388-2853

mjcc@together.net

________________________________________

The Mary Johnson Children's Center will promote the health and happiness of children and respect for families. The Center serves families from throughout Addison County in an early childhood program designed for children 18 months to 6 years old and in after school programs for children 6-12 years old. The center is a collaborative partner with Head Start, and serves a significant population of low-income children and children needing therapeutic child care.

The Center is in need of accurate data showing the health and well-being of children birth to 6 years and their families. For example: housing, heating, income, health and dental care, etc.

Related career areas: Children's Programs, Education, and Social Service.

Applicable academic disciplines include: Teacher Education, Economics, Computer Science, and Sociology/Anthropology.

COVERAGE
ANALYSIS

 

"I'm George Lane's niece," writes Amanda Bradford. "I was there with my uncle when he had to appear in court the first time we went. They did not ask us if we wanted any help." Read letter.

  
George Lane -- hero or hellion?

by Mary Johnson


George Lane, 40, has been arrested more than 30 times on charges that include drunken driving, drugs and traffic offenses, writes the Associated Press's Bill Poovey.

Recent pieces published about the ADA Tenn. v. Lane case, which the Supremes will hear on Tues. (Jan 13), offer a good example of how facts can be parlayed by reporters to create completely different -- and almost opposite -- impressions.

Late last week, Bill Poovey of Tennessee's Associated Press reported on plaintiff George Lane like this:

Eight years ago, after an auto wreck left him unable to walk, George Lane crawled up two flights of stairs at the Polk County Courthouse to face reckless driving charges. He says he will never forget the humiliation of having to drag his body up 30 tile steps. "Two law enforcement officers and county officials stood at the top and laughed," he says. ... Lane, 40, has been arrested more than 30 times and charges that include drunken driving, drugs and traffic offenses. No longer in a wheelchair, Lane now uses an artificial leg to walk inside the razor-topped fences at Brushy Mountain Correctional Complex, where he is serving time for slamming a fellow prisoner in the head with a crutch at a county jail. ... Courthouse employees who witnessed Lane's crawl in Benton, about 40 miles from Chattanooga, say that no one laughed and that he refused offers of help. In fact, Lane declined a judge's offer to move the hearing to a ground-floor room; he says he wanted to be treated like everyone else.

On Sunday, the New York Times's Adam Cohen wrote a remarkable Editorial Observer column about the case. It comes close, almost, to the kind of editorializing that was done in the past about civil rights issues -- that is to say, the reporter is outraged at the facts of the case and sees it as important -- pretty amazing for a NYTimes editorial page that has been lukewarm, at best, to disability rights.

Here's how Cohen reported on the facts of George Lane:

When George Lane showed up at the Polk County Courthouse with a crushed hip and pelvis, he had a problem. His hearing was on the second floor, there was no elevator, and the judge said he had better get upstairs. Mr. Lane, both of whose legs were in casts, somehow managed to get out of his wheelchair and crawl up two flights of stairs. "On a pain scale of 1 to 10, it was way past 10," he says. While Mr. Lane crawled up, he says, the judge and other courthouse employees "stood at the top of the stairs and laughed at me." His case was not heard in the morning session, he says, and at the lunch break he crawled back down. That afternoon, when he refused to crawl upstairs again, he was arrested for failing to appear, and put in jail....

George Lane was working two jobs when he got into the car accident that led to his court appearance. Mr. Lane, who had had minor run-ins with the law before, was not popular with the courthouse crowd in his rural Tennessee county. The employees who laughed at him offered to carry him upstairs, he says, but he was afraid they would intentionally drop him. (The judge who presided that day is no longer alive; the court clerk says she was not present.)

Besides showing us the different skill level of the writers, these two clips show clearly how the same facts can be massaged to create different images and bring forth different emotions in the reader. Poovey's Jones seems almost to deserve his fate, whereas Cohen's Jones comes across not as blameless but certainly as a man who has been denied his rights and in the most humiliating of ways.

The facts of this case are so outrageous that they should have been drawing good press all along -- but the press is just now starting. Some crips are planning to crawl up the Supreme Court steps on Tuesday -- we'll see how that affects coverage, if at all.

Let's be particularly attentive to how the facts of George Lane get reported; what kind of a picture reporters and editorial writers paint of the plaintiff, and how much this influences any commentary there may be. Recall that the Supremes voted in favor of Casey Martin because they liked him, because he was a "courageous young man."

Though it should have nothing to do with the legal rightness of the law, a plaintiff's moral qualities, or lack thereof, often play a large role in cases. That's why Rosa Parks is remembered as the woman who wouldn't go to the back of the bus. The movement chose her to be the symbol because her personal life was above reproach. Plenty of other blacks had refused to move to the back of the bus; but the civil rights organizers turned her refusal into a case because they knew she would play well in the media.

Posted Jan. 12, 2004

Mary Johnson is editor of Ragged Edge.

WHAT DO YOU THINK of what you've just read? Click to tell us.

Readers respond...

I'm George Lane's niece. I was there with my uncle when he had to appear in court the first time we went. They did not ask us if we wanted any help. I helped him up the stairs while the officers laughed at us. (He is not at Brushy Mountain Correctional Complex for slamming a fellow prisoner in the head -- he is there for Violation of Probation. He was not charged for anything causing the wreck.)

The second time he had to appear in court he asked the judge to move [the hearing] down to the public library, but he refused. Then the judge ordered a bench warrant [for his arrest], knowing that he was downstairs, knowing that he had had a hard time getting up the stairs earlier that day.

Court people are not there to judge people [but] to uphold the law -- not their feelings.

Thank you for listening to what really happened.

Amanda Bradford, Cleveland, TN
